(1 Nephi 21:6)."A light to the Gentiles." The aged seer Simeon, who was promised he would not die before seeing the Messiah, saw the baby Jesus in the temple where Mary and Joseph had gone to make an offering. Simeon declared, "Mine eyes have seen thy salvation. … A light to lighten the Gentiles." (Luke 2:25-32.)

Isaiah had also previously referred to the Savior in these terms. (Isaiah 42:6.) He who declared Himself to be the "life and the light of the world" (D&C 11:28) also called Joseph Smith "a light unto the Gentiles." (D&C 86:11.) Nevertheless, the Lord commanded all members of His church to "Arise and shine forth, that thy light may be a standard for the nations." (D&C 115:5.)
